text:
PIONEER EXPERIENCES

A word of explanation to the person answering this questionnaire.

It is difficult to prepare a general questionnaire on pioneer life because no individual who is asked to answer it has exactly the same experiences as another. Some of the questions here will not apply to your experience; others may prove impossible for you to answer, so try to be brief about leaving blank spaces.

The extra sheets of paper if necessary, should be sufficient space to answer the questions. Don't hesitate to give details, or describe particular events, if they help to answer the questions.

This questionnaire is intended for persons who lived in Western Canada before 1924, and may be answered by anyone who has personal experience of the pioneer years whether born in this province or not.

If more than one member of the family can answer the questions, they should write them on separate sheets or apply for a separate questionnaire.

Other Questionnaires

Saskatchewan Archives have which have been prepared or projected are listed below. Please mark the ones you would be willing to answer.

- All questionnaires
- Pioneer diet
- Pioneer schools
- Pioneer churches
- Pioneer recreation and social life
- Pioneer farming experiences
- Pioneers in Saskatchewan
- Pioneer health and housing

Preservation of Questionnaires

All questionnaires will be preserved in the office of the Saskatchewan Archives at the University of Saskatchewan as part of the permanent record of our Province. Please send your completed questionnaire to:

Saskatchewan Archives Office,
University of Saskatchewan,
Saskatoon, Saskatchewan.
PIONEER EXPERIENCES: A GENERAL QUESTIONNAIRE

1. Your full name: William Shillington
2. Your address: 123 Main Ave, Saskatoon
3. Date: May 30th, 1953
4. Where were you born? Carberry, Manitoba, Canada
5. What was your father's name and occupation? Geo Shillington, Farmer
6. When did you come to Saskatchewan? March 21st, 1905
7. Mention any other places where you lived before coming to Saskatoon, giving dates wherever possible.
   - Carberry, Man
8. How old were you when you first came to Western Canada? (You do not need to answer this question if you would rather not or you may use "I was a small child," "I was in my teens," etc.) 22 years
9. What were your reasons for coming West?
   - My Father Mother three Sisters and Five Brothers
   - Also My Wife and Daughter came too
   - My brothers Russell and Herman also got homesteads at Delisle
10. How did you learn about the West? (Through other people? Reading about it? Railroad or government information?) Through other people going before
    And New that had been here through the rebellion
    Also my Uncle and Aunt Mr. and Mrs. Go Little were living on Second Ave South of the Bank of Commerce. Uncle had a blacksmith shop there. They came here in 1902. They are now living at 124 Spadina Ave - present city. My uncle's brother Andrew Little was preaching here at Knox Presbyterian Church here in 1901.

At Knox Presbyterian Church here in 1901.
1. Your full name: John Shillington

2. Your address: 2391 Cty Rd Ave, Saskatchewan

3. Date: May 30th, 1933

4. Where were you born? (Give name of place and country): Carberry, Manitoba, Canada

5. What was your father's name and occupation?: Carberry, Farmer

6. When did you come to Saskatchewan? (Give month and year): March 21st, 1905

7. Mention any other places where you lived before coming to Saskatchewan, giving dates wherever possible.: None

8. How old were you when you first came to Western Canada? (You do not need to answer this question if you would rather not or you may say I was a small child, I was in my teens, etc.): 22 years

9. What were your reasons for coming West?: My Father Mother, three Sisters and Five Brothers Also Mr. Wise and Mrs. Daughter came too. My brothers Russell and Herman also got homesteads at Delisle

10. How did you learn about the West? (Through other people? Reading about it? Railroad or government information?): And New that had been here through the rebellion

Also my Uncle and Aunt Mr. and Mrs. Geal Little were living on Second Ave South of the bank of Toumcerce. Uncle had a blacksmith shop there. They came here in 1902. They are now living at 1245 Spadina Ave - Present City. My uncles brother Andrew Little was preaching here at Knox Presbyterian church here in 1901.

At Knox Presbyterian church here in 1901.
SASKATCHEWAN ARCHIVES QUESTIONNAIRE

PIONEER EXPERIENCES: A GENERAL QUESTIONNAIRE

NOTE: Please print all proper names and place names in capital letters. If you are not sure the name is correct as you have given it, please say so. It is quite acceptable to have someone else do the writing at your direction.

1. Your full name ..............................................................
2. Your address ..................................................................
3. Date .............................................................................
4. Where were you born? (Give name of place and country).
5. What was your father's name and occupation?
6. When did you come to Saskatchewan? (Give month and year).
7. Mention any other places where you lived before coming to Saskatchewan, giving dates wherever possible.
8. How old were you when you first came to Western Canada? (You do not need to answer this question if you would rather not or you may use "I was a small child", "I was in my teens", etc.). 22 Years.
9. What were your reasons for coming West?
My Father Mother three Sisters and Five Brothers
Also My Wife and one Daughter came too.
My brothers Russell and Herman also got homesteads at Delisle
10. How did you learn about the West? (Through other people? Reading about it? Railroad or government information?) Through other people going before
And new that had been here through the new Rebellion
Also my Uncle and Aunt Mr. and Mrs. Go little were living on Second Ave South of the bank of Commerce. Uncle had a blacksmith shop there. They came here in 1902. They are now living at 124 Spadina Ave present city. My Uncle's brother Andrew little was preaching at present. City. My Uncle's brother Andrew little was preaching at Knox Presbyterian Church here in 1901.
NOTE: Please print all proper names and place names in capital letters. If you are not sure the name is correct as you have given it, please say so. It is quite acceptable to have someone else do the writing at your dictation.

1. Your full name: John Shillington
2. Your address: 4217 C.R. Ave., SASKATCHEWAN
3. Date: MAY 30th, 1955
4. Where were you born? (Give name of place and country).
   CABERRY, MANITOBA CANADA
5. What was your father's name and occupation?
   Geo Shillington, Farmer
6. When did you come to Saskatchewann? (Give month and year).
   MARCH 21st, 1905
7. Mention any other places where you lived before coming to Saskatchewann, giving dates wherever possible.
   CABERRY, MAN
   NONE
8. How old were you when you first came to Western Canada? (You do not need to answer this question if you would rather not or you may use "I was a small child", "I was in my teens", etc.) 22 YEARS
9. What were your reasons for coming West?
   MY FATHER, MOTHER, THREE SISTERS AND FIVE BROTHERS
   ALSO MY WIFE AND ONE DAUGHTER CAME TOO.
   MY BROTHERS RUSSELL AND HERMAN ALSO GOT HOME STEADS AT DELISLE
10. How did you learn about the West? (Through other people? Reading about it? Railroad or government information?) THROUGH OTHER PEOPLE GOING BEFORE
    AND NEW THAT HAD BEEN HERE THROUGH THE REAL REBELLION
    ALSO MY UNCLE AND AUNT MR. AND MRS. GOLITTLE WERE LIVING ON
    SECOND AVE SOUTH OF THE BANK OF COMMERCE. UNCLES HAD A BLACKSMITH SHOP THERE. THEY CAME HERE IN 1902. THEY ARE NOW LIVING AT 1245 PARK AVENUE PRESENT CITY. MY UNCLE'S BROTHER ANDREW LITTLE WAS PREACHING AT KIVOX PRESBYTERIAN CHURCH HERE IN 1901.
11. What did your friends and relatives think of your decision to come to Western Canada? They advised me to go and get a homestead.

12. Did you travel by yourself or with a party (family, friends or other group)? My brothers Russell and Herman came with me in freight cars as we had four cars of stock and machinery.

13. What means of transportation did you use? We came by freight to Saskatoon and our family camped by passenger train.

Then we unloaded our stock and machinery at the Stockyard Avenue A Delisle, and rented a house while we moved everything to the farm at Delisle.

14. What incidents of the journey West do you remember? (People you met on the way, meetings with Indians, adventures on the journey, accidents or other excitement, etc.) Every place west of us we were asked where we had our claim.

When we were coming from Regina we passed a large flock of antelope being the first we had ever seen. Also a number of Indians were camped along the road. A few days after we arrived in Saskatoon the bridge went out when the ice broke and everything had to cross the river on the ferry until the bridge was repaired again.

15. Where did you first stay when you arrived in Saskatchewan? We rented a house on Ave C to stay in while we moved our supplies being four carloads to the farm of my father which he bought with a frame house and barn made of sods being 36 miles from here, 7 miles N.W. of Delisle.

16. Where did you settle or take up land? North west of Delisle 9 miles to my farm, where built a frame shanty and 50 acres.

17. Mention any other places where you have lived since coming to Saskatchewan. At Floral East of Saskatoon from 1918 to 1923 from 1928 to 1934 Delisle from 1933 to 1938 lived in New Britain Corn USA and from 1932 to 1934 I lived on a farm south of Humboldt until my health went bad then I had to move to my present address.

18. How did you earn a living before coming to Western Canada? How, after you came?

Farming in Manitoba. After 9 came here I rented a farm but had it hailed out completely. I cut prairie wool hay and the oat crop came up the second time to make feed for the stock.
11. What did your friends and relatives think of your decision to come to Western Canada? They advised me to go and get a homeestead.

12. Did you travel by yourself or with a party (family, friends or other group)? My brothers Russell and Harold came with me in freight cars as we had four cars of stock and machinery.

13. What means of transportation did you use? We came by freight to Saskatoon and our family came by passenger train. Then we unloaded our stock and machinery and put the stock in a barn six miles away at Delisle. We rented a house while we moved everything to the farm at Delisle.

14. What incidents of the journey west do you remember? (People you met on the way, meetings with Indians, adventures on the journey, accidents or other excitement, etc.) Every place we stayed we were asked where we had our claim. Where we were coming from. Regina was passed along. Antelope being the first we had ever seen. Also a number of Indians were camped along the road. A few days after we arrived in Saskatoon the bridge went out when the ice broke and everything had to cross the river on the ferry until the bridge was repaired again.

15. Where did you first stay when you arrived in Saskatchewan? We rented a house on Avenue C to stay in while we moved our supplies being four carloads to the farm of my father which he bought with a frame house and barn made of sods being 36 miles from here, 7 miles north west of Delisle.

16. Where did you settle or take up land? Mention any other places where you have lived since coming to Saskatchewan. At Floral East of Saskatoon from 1918 to 1923. From 1928 to 1932 at Delisle. From 1932 to 1938 I lived in New Britain Conn USA and from 1932 to 1944 I lived on a farm south of Humboldt until my health went bad then I had to move to my present address.

17. How did you earn a living before coming to Western Canada? How, after you came?

Farming in Manitoba. After 9 came here I rented a farm but had it hauled out completely. Got prairie wool hay and the oat crop came up the second time to make feed for the stock.
19. How often did you write to relatives or friends in your old home?
   About twice a month.

20. If you got married, give the name of your husband or wife along with the
    date and place of marriage.
    John May Peacock, Feb. 15th, 1903, Carberry, Man.

21. Did anyone else come to Saskatchewan because of your recommendation? It was a
    yes there were a number came excluding my wives family of five.

22. If other members of your family (brothers, sisters, parents, etc.) came West
    tell when they came and where they settled.
    Father, Mother's 3 sisters and 5 brothers and 2 brother-in-laws
    Father bought a section of land and the other two brothers Russell and
    Herman got homesteads northwest of Delisle. One brother-in-law got homesteaded at
    persley while the other one Tom Peacock got his at Langham.

23. Is there any particular experience of pioneer days that stands out in your
    memory which you would like to record? Breaking with an oxen on a walkin' plow.
    A number of fires broke out and one got around me and kept close.

For over a half mile which shall never forget the heat and roar in the grass I
as I just beat it to a fire guard. In 1908 I was left alone with my wife when our
third child was born when we had the threshers and we could not get a doctor. My
brother Russell came along after the baby Edna was born and he to my father's farm 1/2 miles away and brought my
mother which was a great relief to me. Also when we went out with our first
load of oats on a mile from home a brass band struck up at the home of the late Henry Mohr.

24. Did you travel about much in the early years? (For business attending church, visiting friends, etc.) How often? How far? By what means of
    travel?
    We had to draw our wheat over thirty miles to Saskatoon and used to sell to
    the late Archie McNab who later became Lieut Gov of Sask.
    We also had Dr. Munro for supper on the farm. He later became Lieut Gov. Previous to
    Archie McNab, we used to visit or go to church in busy as we were very close. I have
    As the school where we held church and entertainment was on my
    Father's land Sec. 6, Tp 35 Rg 10 W of 3rd. We used horses for all work except food.
    The first year I broke 20 acres with a pair of oxen while the Mares raised.
19. How often did you write to relatives or friends in your old home?

About twice a month.

20. If you got married, give the name of your husband or wife along with the date and place of marriage.

Sidney May Peacock, Feb. 5th, 1903, Carberry, Man.

21. Did anyone else come to Saskatchewan because of your recommendation? Yes, there were a number came including my wives family of five.

22. If other members of your family (brothers, sisters, parents, etc.) came West tell who they came and where they settled.

Father, Mother, 3 aunts and brothers and brother-in-law's.

Father bought a section of land and the other two brothers Russell and Herman got homesteads northwest of Delisle. One brother-in-law, girl homesteaded at Plesis, while the other one Tom Paddock got his at Langton.

23. Is there any particular experience of pioneer days that stands out in your memory which you would like to record? Breaking with oxen on a tall prairie.

A number of fires broke out and we got around me and kept close.

For over one half mile which shall never forget the heat and roar in the grass.

As I just beat it to a fire guard. In 1908 I was left alone with my wife when our third child was born when we had the threshers and we could not get a doctor. My brother Russell came along after the baby Edna was born and he took my father's farm 1/2 miles away and brought my mother which was a great relief to me. Also when we went out with our first load of wheat on a mile farm, we had a horseback stretch up at the home of the late Henry Mohr.

24. Did you travel about much? (for business, attending church, visiting friends, etc.) How far? By what means of travel?

We had to draw our wheat over thirty miles to Saskatoon and used to sell to the late Archie Mswab who later became Lieutenant of Sask.

We also had Dr. Munro for supper on the farm. He later became Lieutenant.

Archie Mswab used to visit our church in Wabuno as we were very close. I have As the school where we held church and entertainment was on my Father's land. See p. 35 of R. G. U. O. F. 3rd grade used horses for all work except food.

The first year we broke to acres with a pair of oxen while the mare raised colts.
25. When was the first car used in the community?
   1916 Model T Ford was my first car.

26. If you owned a car before 1914, when did you buy it? What make?

27. Where was your trading center? How far from your home?
   First two years: Saskatoon townsite, then Delisle 9 miles.

28. Did you continue to trade there? (Indicate any changes due to new towns appearing, better means of travel, etc.)
   Yes, we moved to Delisle.

29. Did you continue to trade there? (Indicate any changes due to new towns appearing, better means of travel, etc.)
   Yes, we moved to Delisle.

30. Did you continue to trade there? (Indicate any changes due to new towns appearing, better means of travel, etc.)
   Yes, we moved to Delisle.

31. What kind of articles did you buy in this way? Indicate also what proportion of your total purchases were by mail order since the pioneer period.
   We always sent one order each winter for such things as socks, rubber mitts, underwear, blankets, boots, clothing, and other supplies.

32. When did you first have a telephone and what company provided it?
   1912 had telephone installed by the local farmers through local organization.

33. When you came to Saskatchewan the first time was it with the idea of staying permanently? Or did you make up your mind after trying it out? When did you make this decision?
   By the fall of 1904 my father came to Saskatoon and hired a man to drive him out to look at some land where he bought a section N.W. of Delisle. We came with the intention of staying and have never been sorry as we feel there is no place like good old Saskatoon.
25. When was the first car used in the community?

26. If you owned a car before 1914, when did you buy it? What make?

27. Where was your trading center? How far from your home?

28. Did you continue to trade there? (Indicate any changes due to new towns opening, better means of travel, etc.)

29. Did you move, or did you move to its present location?

30. How often did you shop in the early days?

31. When did you first begin to buy through the mail order catalogs?

32. What kind of supplies did you buy by mail order and any changes in the proportion of purchases made by mail order since the pioneer period?

33. When did you first have a telephone and what company provided it?

34. In what year did you come to Saskatchewan the first time and why did you make this decision?

35. In the fall of 1904 my father came to Saskatoon and hired a man to drive him out to look at some land where he bought a section N.W. of Delisle. We came with the intention of staying and have never been sorry. As we feel there is no place like old Saskatoon.
34. Did any people move away from your district prior to 1924? What reasons did they have for moving?

There were a number who sold their homesteads after getting the title and going back to their previous homes or other places as other farmers were buying more land as their family grew up. There were a number of buyers came from eastern Canada and bought a lot of the land mostly of German descent.

35. Did many people move away during the 1930s? Did many return?

Yes, a number sold their land and went north while others went into other business or trades or retired. None have returned.

36. If you or some member of your family have held public office, or have been active in any organizations, mention it here, giving dates wherever possible.

Yes, my father was a councillor at Athabasca while he lived on the farm. Also Superintendent of the Sunday School at Athabasca where he farmed.

37. If you or any of your family or friends have been involved in any organizations (such as the local branch of the Royal Canadian Legion, etc.) or owning the first assembly, combine organizing first lodge, etc., etc.

My father, my brothers Russell, Herman, myself and a number of neighbours organized Loganton Orange Lodge No. 185 in 1906. After the railroad came in it was moved to Laura.

38. How did the places in your community get their names? (School districts, post offices, villages, railway stations, creeks, hills, etc.)

Name called after Fleet Logue. Logue Station was named after him. It was called after the railroad came. Delisle got its name from a family of that name one of the early settlers who have since moved to the Peace River Country.
34. Did any people move away from your district prior to 1924? What reasons did they have for moving?

There were a number of people who sold their homesteads after getting the title and going back to their previous homes or other places. As other farmers were buying more land as their family grew up, there were a number of buyers came from eastern Canada and bought a lot of the land. Many of these men came from eastern Canada and bought a lot of the land.

35. Did many people move away during the 1930s? Did many return?

Yes, a number sold their land and went north while others went into other business or trades or retired. None have returned.

36. If you or some member of your family have held public office, or have been active in any organizations, mention it here, giving dates wherever possible.

Yes, my father was a councillor at Wamsley while he lived on the farm. Also Superintendent of the Sunday School at Avondale where he farmed.

37. If you or any of your family or friends were forced to have or do some thing in the district which you believe should not have been done, whether personal, political, or otherwise, what was it?

My father, my brothers Russell, Herman, myself and a number of neighbours organized Loganton Orange Lodge No. 185 in 1906. After the railroad came in it was moved to Laura.

38. How did the places in your community get their names? (School districts, post offices, villages, railway stations, creeks, hills, etc.)

Try to give (1) name and occupation of person suggesting place-name; (2) origin and meaning of the name; (3) date of its adoption; (4) any changes in names since the first name was given; (5) date and reason for change; give facts of new name as above in (1), (2), (3).

Delisle got its name from a family of that name one of the early settlers who have since moved to the Peace River Country.
Questions regarding historical source materials:

Do you have in your possession or do you know the whereabouts of diaries, old letters, old posters and programs, minute books of community organizations, old pamphlets, old photographs, written recollections and reminiscences? (Describe).

Mrs. Elizabeth Frey was the first woman that lived in that district, living in a tent alone on the prairie while her husband was away drawing supplies.

Would you or the person who owns them either:
(1) be willing to lend them to the Provincial Archivist for copying?
(2) be willing to present them to the Archives Division of the Legislative Library? (Indicate your preference, if any) ____________________________

If you have children or grandchildren, please give their names, where they live and occupations.

Greene May, Mrs. Albert Bestwood, Louise Weyant, Mrs. Katherine Smith, Sherry Glenn, Miss Mildred McKee, Bobbie Sheryl

John Ernest Asquith, farming, single
Edna Lenore, deceased, Mrs. Walter McAllister
Gordon Beverley, Sashatoon C.N.R. Breakman

40. If you have children or grandchildren, please give their names, where they live and occupations.

Grandchildren Great Grandchildren
Greene May, Mrs. Albert Bestwood, Louise Weyant, Mrs. Katherine Smith, Sherry Glenn, Miss Mildred McKee, Bobbie Sheryl

41. What do you think are the most important changes in your community since you first came here?

Land all broken up and operated by large farmers who have torn the buildings down or moved them into the city or town; also the absence of livestock that the farmers previously had kept. The roads have been improved very much and the farmers are able to keep the weeds down much better with the modern machinery.

Please give the names and addresses of other pioneers who could answer this question.

907m Downey, 1235 Ave B Worth
Henry Gesty Delisle
Carl Mohr Asquith

If someone else has filled in this questionnaire for you, please have this person give name and address here!
Questions regarding Historical source materials:

Do you have in your possession or do you know the whereabouts of diaries, all types of old papers and programs, old photographs, written recollections and reminiscences? (Describe).

Mrs. Elizabeth Frey was the first woman that lived in that district, living in a tent above on the prairie while her husband was away drawing supplies.

They were the first homesteaders in the Avondale District.

Would you or the person who owns them either:
(1) be willing to lend them to the Provincial Archivist for copying?
(2) be willing to present them to the Archives Division of the Legislative Library, Regina, or the archives office at the University in Saskatoon?

Indicate your preference, if any.

If you have children or grandchildren, please give their names, where they live and occupations.

First name May, now Mrs. Albert Bestwood, now living nearby.

Grandchildren: Great Grandfather: John Ernest, Asquith, farming, Swistle; Edna Lenore, deceased, now Mrs. Alfred Haggart; Gordon Beverley, Saskatoon, CNR, Breakman.

What do you think are the most important changes in your community since you first came here?

Land all broken up and operated by large farmers who have torn the buildings down or moved them into the city or town, also the absence of livestock that the farmers previously had kept.

The roads have been improved very much and the farmers are able to keep the weeds down much better with the modern machinery.

Please give the names and addresses of other pioneers who could answer this questionnaire.

97th Downey, 1235 Ave B North

Henry Geary Delisle

Carl Mohr Asquith
